body:
Building pandas master (which works with cython 0.29.x) with the 3.0a9 I'm getting a segfault in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/_libs/hashtable_func_helper.pxi.in#L110

lldb is pointing me towards a `__Pyx_INCREF` call:

```
frame #1: 0x000000011da6ef72 hashtable.cpython-39-darwin.so`__pyx_pw_6pandas_5_libs_9hashtable_73__pyx_fuse_12duplicated [inlined] __pyx_f_6pandas_5_libs_9hashtable_duplicated_object(__pyx_v_values=0x0000000000000000, __pyx_optional_args=<unavailable>) at hashtable.c:101383 [opt]
   101380	 *         raise ValueError('keep must be either "first", "last" or False')
   101381	 * 
   101382	 */
-> 101383	  __Pyx_INCREF(__pyx_v_keep);
   101384	  __pyx_t_2 = __pyx_v_keep;
   101385	  __pyx_t_9 = (__Pyx_PyUnicode_Equals(__pyx_t_2, __pyx_n_u_last, Py_NE)); if (unlikely((__pyx_t_9 < 0))) __PYX_ERR(3, 1504, __pyx_L1_error)
   101386	  if (__pyx_t_9) {
```

Not sure if this means anything, but sublimetext's syntax highlighting seems to stop about 60k lines before this

comment_data.body:
It looks from that traceback as if `values` is being passed a NULL pointer (which is probably a Cython bug, but likely happening a little further up the traceback).

Could you tell us what code you're running to get it to crash?

@jbrockmendel do you know which case is crashing here? Is the caller passing `keep` in or is it using the default value?

(Note that it's not `values` being passed as `NULL` but the `keep` argument.)

It's the object-dtype `duplicated` case.  It segfaults with or without passing `keep`:

```
import numpy as np
from pandas._libs import hashtable as ht

arr = np.arange(100).astype(object)

ht.duplicated(arr)  # <- segfault
ht.duplicated(arr, "first") # <- segfault
ht.duplicated(arr, keep="first") # <- segfault
```

The following Pandas-free example reproduces the bug:

```
ctypedef fused F:
    double
    int

cpdef duplicated(F val, object keep="first"):
    if keep not in ('last', 'first', False):
        raise ValueError('keep must be either "first", "last" or False')
```

It's to do with default values on `cpdef` fused functions
The commit at issue looks to be ee7ae0b9ce0dea51cf17adf119afe439917ee4c0 - I suspect it just needs a little special-casing for cpdef functions
Awesome, looking forward to trying it out again.
I did have a go at trying to run through the Pandas test-suite with this fix but unfortunately "hypothesis" outsmarted me (so nothing useful to report...)

> I did have a go at trying to run through the Pandas test-suite with this fix but unfortunately "hypothesis" outsmarted me (so nothing useful to report...)

i just tried running the tests using cython master and am getting the same segfaults from https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4409#issuecomment-944387175

For me latest Cython master+latest Pandas master and the code in the comment https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4409#issuecomment-944387175 seems to work fine.

I can't get the pandas tests to run at all - running `pytest pandas/tests/libs` just gives me:

```
ImportError while loading conftest '<path>/pandas/conftest.py'.
pandas/conftest.py:489: in <module>
    "datetime": tm.makeDateIndex(100),
pandas/_testing/__init__.py:364: in makeDateIndex
    dr = bdate_range(dt, periods=k, freq=freq, name=name)
pandas/core/indexes/datetimes.py:1172: in bdate_range
    return date_range(
pandas/core/indexes/datetimes.py:1061: in date_range
    dtarr = DatetimeArray._generate_range(
pandas/core/arrays/datetimes.py:448: in _generate_range
    values = np.array([x.value for x in xdr], dtype=np.int64)
pandas/core/arrays/datetimes.py:448: in <listcomp>
    values = np.array([x.value for x in xdr], dtype=np.int64)
pandas/core/arrays/datetimes.py:2548: in generate_range
    start = offset.rollforward(start)
pandas/_libs/tslibs/offsets.pyx:639: in pandas._libs.tslibs.offsets.BaseOffset.rollforward
    dt = dt + type(self)(1, normalize=self.normalize, **self.kwds)
E   TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'Timestamp' and 'pandas._libs.tslibs.offsets.BusinessDay'
```

so I don't think I can investigate this myself.
Good point, the branch I've been using to try out cython3 implements `__radd__`, `__rsub__`, and `__rmul__`: https://github.com/jbrockmendel/pandas/tree/cy3

So running `pytest pandas/tests/libs` on your cy3 branch I get:

```
============================================= test session starts ==============================================
platform linux -- Python 3.8.12, pytest-6.2.5, py-1.11.0, pluggy-1.0.0
rootdir: <path>/pandas, configfile: pyproject.toml
plugins: cython-0.1.1.post0, instafail-0.4.2, xdist-2.4.0, hypothesis-6.27.2, forked-1.3.0, asyncio-0.16.0, cov-3.0.0
collected 461 items                                                                                            

pandas/tests/libs/test_hashtable.py ..................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................
pandas/tests/libs/test_join.py .................
pandas/tests/libs/test_lib.py ..........

------------------ generated xml file: <path>/pandas/test-data.xml -------------------
============================================= slowest 30 durations =============================================
0.01s call     pandas/tests/libs/test_hashtable.py::TestHashTable::test_unique[True-Int32HashTable-int32]
0.01s teardown pandas/tests/libs/test_lib.py::test_no_default_pickle
0.01s call     pandas/tests/libs/test_hashtable.py::TestHashTable::test_unique[True-Int8HashTable-int8]

(27 durations < 0.005s hidden.  Use -vv to show these durations.)
============================================= 461 passed in 1.06s ==============================================
```

i.e. it looks fine. Are you sure that all the .pyx files have been rebuilt with the new version of Cython? It only looks at the file modification time and not the Cython version when deciding whether to rebuild, so if Cython's changed and the file hasn't then it won't recythonize.

> Are you sure that all the .pyx files have been rebuilt with the new version of Cython?

Did `python setup.py clean` before re-building.  In a fresh virtualenv, with cython installed from source.  `cython --version` shows "3.0.0a9"; is it possible I somehow installed the released version and not actually master?

My best suggestion would be to find out where Cython's installed (with `import cython; print(cython.__file__)`) and then go look and see if you can find the changes in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4413/files. But I don't know. I'm personally fairly convinced it is fixed, but that doesn't help you too much...
Looks like I've got the right version, so it's a mystery.  I'll try on a different platform next week.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: [BUG] segfault on pandas with 3.0a9
